DOCNAME: AFONSO and ANTONIO v. THE NETHERLANDS
TEXT: The applicants , PERSON and her daughter PERSON , are NORP nationals , who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in FAC . They are represented before the ORG by Mr J.J. Eizenga , a lawyer practising in ‘ s - Hertogenbosch .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicants , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE , the first applicant married Mr GPE in a traditional ceremony in GPE . They had CARDINAL children , PERSON ( born in DATE ) , PERSON ( born in DATE ) and the second applicant .

In DATE , Mr GPE fled from GPE to the GPE , where he applied for asylum . He was eventually granted a residence permit on grounds of a policy of tolerance ( gedoogdenbeleid ) , i.e. where expulsion would entail undue hardship given the general situation in the country of origin . The first applicant and the CARDINAL children continued to live in GPE ( GPE ) .

On DATE , the CARDINAL applicants travelled from GPE to GPE for which country they had obtained an entry visa . On DATE , they travelled from GPE to the GPE , where on DATE they applied for asylum . The CARDINAL other children , PERSON and PERSON , remained in GPE in the care of a friend . When interviewed on DATE by a GPE immigration official on the reasons for her asylum request , the first applicant stated that she had applied for asylum in the GPE because her husband was living there , of which fact she had become aware in DATE .

On DATE , ORG requested that GPE accept responsibility for the applicants’ asylum request pursuant to LAW . On DATE , the NORP authorities accepted that responsibility . The GPE Deputy Minister of Justice ( ORG ) subsequently declared inadmissible the applicants’ asylum request . The ORG appeal was rejected in a final decision taken by ORG ( arrondissementsrechtbank ) on DATE .

In the meantime , on DATE , the first applicant applied for a residence permit to stay with her husband . She also made this application on behalf of the second applicant . Holding that the first applicant had not established the existence of a legally valid marriage with Mr GPE by way of authenticated official documents , and that Mr GPE did not comply with the minimum income requirement under the applicable immigration rules ( i.e. the equivalent of MONEY per month ) , the Deputy Minister of ORG rejected this request on DATE and issued an order for the applicants’ expulsion .

On DATE , the first applicant filed an objection ( bezwaar ) against this decision with the Deputy Minister and , on DATE , requested the President of ORG to issue an interim measure to the effect that she would not be expelled pending the proceedings on her objection .
On DATE , Mr GPE was granted GPE nationality .

On DATE , considering that the Deputy Minister had considerably exceeded the statutory time - limit for determining the applicant ’s objection , and thus apparently attached no great importance to an expulsion at short notice , the President of ORG granted the interim measure requested by the first applicant .

On DATE , the Deputy Minister of ORG withdrew the policy decision in force since DATE to stay expulsions to GPE given the general situation there . The decision to withdraw this moratorium was based on the official reports ( ambtsberichten ) of DATE and CARDINAL DATE of ORG , according to which the general situation in GPE had improved .

According to a further official report of DATE of ORG , the security situation in GPE had considerably improved since DATE when the warring NORP Government forces and the ORG rebel forces signed an official ceasefire agreement in the form of a Memorandum of Understanding in order to pave the way for further negotiations on a political level . The report stated that both the Government and ORG forces respected the ceasefire agreement . However , some incidents of armed plundering , mostly caused by hungry former ORG fighters , had still occurred , which incidents could not always be effectively countered by the NORP police forces . Certain former unsafe areas could therefore not yet be classified as secure . Areas now classified as safe were the capital GPE , the coastal areas of the provinces ORG , PERSON , PERSON and ORG , and all the provincial capitals .

On DATE , the applicant was heard on her objection before an official committee ( ambtelijke commissie ) . On DATE , the Deputy Minister of ORG rejected the applicant ’s objection and ordered her expulsion from the GPE . On DATE , the first applicant filed an appeal ( beroep ) against this decision with ORG and , on DATE , requested the President of ORG to issue an interim measure allowing her to remain in the GPE pending the proceedings on her appeal .
In its decision of DATE , following a hearing held on DATE , ORG sitting in ‘ s - Hertogenbosch rejected the first applicant ’s appeal ( beroep ) against the decision of DATE .

It noted at the outset that the first applicant had failed to substantiate her marriage with Mr GPE with authenticated documents . It further noted that , pursuant to the applicable statutory immigration rules and the pertaining immigration policy guidelines , it was a material condition for the admission of foreign spouses that the existence of a marriage be shown by official and authenticated documents .

As the first applicant had failed to submit such documents and had failed to undertake any attempts to contact her parents , other relatives or the ( local ) authorities in GPE in order to obtain official and authenticated documents proving her marriage with Mr GPE , ORG concluded that the Deputy Minister had correctly rejected the first applicant ’s request for a residence permit on the grounds of her purported marriage . This finding was not altered by the recording of her marital status , on the basis of an affidavit given by the first applicant , in the municipal personal records database ( gemeentelijke basisadministratie ) of the town where she lived in the GPE , as the statutory provisions on such municipal databases could not be regarded as a specific regulation aimed at implementing statutory immigration rules .
Insofar as the first applicant complained that the refusal to grant her a residence permit was contrary to her rights under LAW , ORG held :
“ It is not disputed that in casu there is family life within the meaning of LAW between [ the first applicant ] , her ( purported ) spouse PERSON and their daughter , PERSON .

The [ Deputy Minister ] has correctly considered that there has been no interference as to the right to respect for family life as meant by LAW as the refusal to allow residence [ in the GPE ] did not entail depriving [ the first applicant ] of a residence title enabling her to enjoy family life .

The question thus arises whether there are facts and circumstances of such a nature that the right to respect for family life would give rise to a positive obligation for the [ Deputy Minister ] nevertheless to grant [ the first applicant ] residence [ in the GPE ] . In order to answer that question , the interests of the [ Deputy Minister ] must be balanced against the interests of [ the first applicant ] . It is of primary importance to attain a “ fair balance ” between those interests , in which the [ Deputy Minister ] enjoys a certain margin of appreciation . An important aspect of this balancing of interests is the question whether it is possible to exercise family life in the country of origin .

ORG is of the opinion that the [ Deputy Minister ] could find in all reasonableness that the [ first applicant ’s ] interests did not outweigh the general interest . In this finding it is important that neither for [ the first applicant ] nor for the other members of her family are there any objective obstacles to the exercise of family life outside the GPE or in GPE , the [ first applicant ’s ] country of origin . In this connection it is equally relevant that the ( purported ) spouse of [ the first applicant ] , who has not been admitted to the GPE as a refugee , also originates from that country . Noting the official reports ( ambtsberichten ) of the Minister of ORG of DATE and CARDINAL DATE , the situation in GPE also does not form an obstacle .

As to the [ first applicant ’s ] argument , based on the judgment of ORG August CARDINAL ... ( LOC v. GPE ) ... , that in her case it should also be examined whether in all reasonableness it can be expected from her husband , in view of his GPE nationality , that he returns to GPE or goes [ with her ] to GPE , ORG considers that it can in all reasonableness be expected of the ( purported ) spouse that he returns to GPE or goes [ with the first applicant ] to GPE to exercise family life there in view of the fact that he ( originally ) comes from GPE and that no objective obstacle has become apparent . Also the health problems advanced by [ the first applicant ] do not necessarily constitute an obstacle to the exercise of family life outside the GPE or in the country of origin as the family ’s separation was [ partly ] the cause of the [ first applicant ’s ] health problems . Furthermore , CARDINAL children of the family still reside in GPE . Also on that ground , ORG fails to see why family life could not be exercised there .

In view of the above considerations , ORG is of the opinion that the [ Deputy Minister } could in all reasonableness conclude that there was no positive obligation to grant [ the first applicant ] residence in the GPE on the grounds of LAW . ”

On DATE , the provisional measures judge ( voorzieningenrechter ) of ORG sitting in ‘ PERSON rejected the first applicant ’s request for an interim measure as her appeal against the decision of DATE had been rejected by ORG .
